summary.abstract: This chapter examines two three-dimensional astronomical instruments in the Islamicate world: celestial globes and armillary spheres. Celestial globes, of which over 200 survive, were used for astronomical observations, calculations, and demonstrations, with their construction influenced by the star catalogues of al-Ṣūfī and the theoretical works of Ptolemy and al-Battānī. The globe-making tradition flourished over a millennium, peaking in Mughal India, especially through the Lahore workshop of the Allāhdād family during the 11th/17th century. Armillary spheres, by contrast, were primarily used for observations in the Islamicate world, constructed as large as possible within major observatory complexes at Baghdad, Damascus, Maragha, and Samarqand. Both instrument types bear evidence of scholarly transmission, patronage networks, and the social institutionalization of astronomy from the 2nd/8th through the 13th/19th centuries.
